title: Can quantum-mechanical description of physical reality be considered complete?
text:
Abstract
In a complete theory there is an element corresponding to each element of reality. A sufficient condition for the reality of a physical quantity is the possibility of predicting it with certainty, without disturbing the system. In quantum mechanics in the case of two physical quantities described by non-commuting operators, the knowledge of one precludes the knowledge of the other. Then either (1) the description of reality given by the wave function in quantum mechanics is not complete or (2) these two quantities cannot have simultaneous reality. Consideration of the problem of making predictions concerning a system on the basis of measurements made on another system that had previously interacted with it leads to the result that if (1) is false then (2) is also false. One is thus led to conclude that the description of reality as given by a wave function is not complete.

title: Can quantum-mechanical description of physical reality be considered complete?

title: Emily K. Johnson
text:
Email
  
  
    
     LinkedIn
  
  
     
  
  
     
  
  
    
     GitHub
  

      


I’m a PhD student at the Danish Centre for Health Economics at the University of Southern Denmark, where I investigate the complex relationships between population health, healthcare expenditures, and disease burden.
My research bridges quantitative methods with real-world health policy challenges, leveraging large-scale health data to understand how we can better allocate resources and improve population outcomes. Before my PhD, I spent four years at the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME) as a Research Scientist, contributing to global burden of disease research that informs health policy worldwide.

title: Emily K. Johnson
text:
Experience
Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation  Research Scientist, 2019-2023

Clinical Informatics researcher, Global Burden of Disease
Integrated Medicare and Medicaid data to IHME data ecosystem
Disease expenditure researcher, US Counties Health Expenditure project

Epic Systems  Technical Services Engineer, 2017-2019

Built EHR reporting of value-based health plans
Supported healthcare data workflows

title: Emily K. Johnson
text:
Education
PhD in Health Economics  University of Southern Denmark  In Progress 
MSc in Health Data Science  London School of Economics  2022 
PgCert in Epidemiology  University of Edinburgh  2022 
BA in Statistics  Rice University  2017

title: Emily K. Johnson
text:
I’m a PhD student at the Danish Centre for Health Economics at the University of Southern Denmark, where I investigate the complex relationships between population health, healthcare expenditures, and disease burden.
My research bridges quantitative methods with real-world health policy challenges, leveraging large-scale health data to understand how we can better allocate resources and improve population outcomes. Before my PhD, I spent four years at the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME) as a Research Scientist, contributing to global burden of disease research that informs health policy worldwide.

title: Emily K. Johnson
text:
Background

EducationExperienceResearch Interests


PhD in Health Economics (In Progress) University of Southern Denmark Focus: Population health, healthcare costs, and economic evaluation
MSc in Health Data Science (2022) London School of Economics Specialized in applying machine learning and statistical methods to health data
PgCert in Epidemiology (2022) University of Edinburgh Advanced training in epidemiological methods and causal inference
BA in Statistics (2017) Rice University Quantitative foundation with honors thesis in biostatistics


Research Scientist (2019-2023) Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation - Contributed to Global Burden of Disease Study - Developed statistical models for disease prevalence estimation - Collaborated with international health organizations
Technical Services Engineer (2017-2019) Epic Systems - Implemented electronic health record systems - Gained hands-on experience with real-world clinical data workflows - Supported healthcare organizations in data optimization



Health Economics: Economic evaluation, cost-effectiveness analysis, healthcare resource allocation
Population Health: Disease burden estimation, health inequalities, social determinants of health
Quantitative Methods: Causal inference, predictive modeling, large-scale data analysis
Health Policy: Evidence-based policy design, health system performance, health equity

title: Emily K. Johnson
text:
Research Interests
Health Economics Healthcare expenditure, resource allocation, systems incentives
Population Health Disease burden estimation, comparative outcomes, fertility, mortality
Quantitative Methods Causal inference, predictive modeling, large-scale data analysis
Health Policy Evidence-based policy, health systems, health equity
